title: GE Capital: the end of the Blob?
text:
Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.  

‘The Blob' takes on a new shape

Is this the end of the Blob? That was Jack Welch's nickname for GE Capital when General Electric reigned supreme at the end of the last century and its financial arm had become the industrial conglomerate's largest business unit. 

As Welch's successor Jeff Immelt puts it in his new book, writes the FT's Andrew Edgecliffe-Johnson, the theory was “don't look at the elements that make up the Blob, just look at the results”. 

Sure enough, Wall Street didn't ask too many questions about what lurked inside GE Capital — at least until the 2008-09 global financial crisis made its liabilities look life-threatening.

In 2008, GE Capital had $660bn of assets, and it was still the largest non-bank lender in the US five years later when its designation as a heavily regulated, systemically relevant financial institution, prompted Immelt to start trying to break it up. 

But prohibitive tax hurdles and a toxic tail of liabilities meant the Blob, like the star of the 1958 sci-fi horror film of the same name, has proved remarkably hard to kill. 

Immelt and both of his successors have hacked away at it for some years, with current chief executive Larry Culp cutting the division's assets from $86bn to $68bn since 2018.

On Wednesday, Culp announced an exit from GE Capital's largest remaining business, the aircraft leasing business GECAS. 

If regulators clear the $30bn-plus sale to Irish rival AerCap, it would bring in $24bn of cash to further cut GE's debt load and let it transfer $34bn of GECAS assets to AerCap, chief financial officer Carolina Dybeck Happe told analysts, making GE “a more focused and simpler industrial company”.

The deal technically marks the end of GE Capital, as the group will no longer break its financial activities out as their own segment, but the Blob isn't quite dead yet. 

GE will own 46 per cent of the combined aircraft leasing company and is keeping GE Capital's business providing financing to its power and renewables customers and a working capital unit. It will also be running off its insurance liabilities for a while yet. 

GE Capital's importance in supporting the group's industrial clients meant rating agencies treated it as a captive finance unit and didn't consolidate its financials in their calculations. That would now change, S&P Global ratings said on Wednesday, as it warned that it might cut GE's credit rating by one notch in response. 

Call it the Blob's revenge.

*One note to readers: We apologise for a technical error that resulted in the lead item in Wednesday's issue being cut short. The full version is available here and the full UAE VIP vaccine story is here.

How Greensill courted private equity months before its collapse

It was autumn 2020, and Greensill Capital was a ticking time bomb. 

The financial technology group's insurers had said they'd pull the cover that was critical to its business model, and Germany's financial watchdog BaFin was asking questions about its ties to metals magnate Sanjeev Gupta. 

Yet, just months before its collapse, it presented a far rosier picture to a line-up of private equity groups. 

Advised by blue-chip names Citigroup, Credit Suisse and Allen & Overy, it launched what it called a “pre-IPO” funding round. It was trying to raise $1bn at a valuation of $7bn — twice the $3.5bn level at which SoftBank had invested the previous year.

The buyout groups weren't impressed with what one described as “The Lex Show”, as Lex Greensill, the company's founder, regaled them with tales of his upbringing as the son of an Australian watermelon farmer. 

Read up on their reaction with this deep-dive by DD's Kaye Wiggins and Rob Smith. 

In other Greensill/private equity news, Apollo's plan to buy parts of the business was crumbling on Wednesday after the US technology company Taulia, which supplies the digital platform used by most of Greensill's customers, looked to move its users to JPMorgan. 

Reminder: if you want to brush up on the long Greensill story, the FT's recent reporting is collected here, and you can watch DD's Rob Smith explaining it all on Australia's ABC News here.

Meanwhile, Japanese insurer Tokio Marine said the insurance policies at the heart of the collapse may not have been valid in the first place, and Insurance Australia Group said it had no “net insurance exposure” to policies sold to Greensill Capital.

And for a glimpse into the real-world impact of the Greensill story, check out this deep-dive from the FT's Sylvia Pfeifer, Oliver Barnes and Jamie Smyth on the industrial empire run by Sanjeev Gupta, who used Greensill as his main lender.

It spans four continents and employs 35,000 people, and has now hired PJT Partners and Alvarez & Marsal to help it secure new financing as it faces its greatest test yet. 

McKinsey: a new era?

Sometimes life hands you a second chance. For Bob Sternfels, the magnitude of reputational crises shaking McKinsey, the consultancy where he has spent the past 25 years, was just enough to shift the odds in his favour.

The 51-year-old San Franciscan was expected to be the favourite in the secretive ballot for the company's top job back in 2017. DD regulars will know how the story ended. Then-Asia Pacific chairman Kevin Sneader ultimately inherited the crown.

But Sternfels was unexpectedly thrown into the mix once more when Sneader failed to qualify for the final round of voting by McKinsey's 650 senior partners. 

This week Sternfels, currently acting in a role akin to chief operating officer, beat out fellow finalist Sven Smit, the Amsterdam-based co-chair of McKinsey's research arm.

It's a new chapter for McKinsey, but certainly not a blank slate.

Over the past several years, the company's signature “mystique” — which meant, among other things, that it was supposed to work only for the most reputable clients — has taken a few hits. Working with Purdue Pharma left a sizeable dent, for one.

Will Sternfels try to get it back, or write his own script?

Surely he's been around long enough to have seen what not to do, as he saw first hand former managing director Rajat Gupta imprisoned for insider trading in 2012.

Winning over McKinsey's senior partners is one thing. Keeping them happy will be a separate challenge. The role is “analogous to running a political party. There are a lot of backbenchers who don't like having a boss,” a former partner told the FT.

Job moves

  • Austrian financier Alexander Schütz, who came under pressure earlier this year over communications with the boss of disgraced payments company Wirecard, is leaving Deutsche Bank's supervisory board. More here.

  • Herbert Smith Freehills has appointed Rebecca Maslen-Stannage as its first female chair. She will remain in Sydney during her four-year term. More here.

  • The Biden administration is vetting prominent tech critic Lina Khan for a senior government role, most likely as commissioner of the Federal Trade Commission. More here.

  • Baby foodmaker Yumi has hired Goldman Sachs partner Sarah-Marie Martin as its chief financial officer.

  • Debevoise & Plimpton is opening a new San Francisco office later this year. Five partners will relocate to spearhead the new territory.

Smart reads 

An inconvenient truth Investors are piling record sums into sustainable investments. But many of these funds are simply “greenwashing” — environmental buzzword-laden rebrands of the same old strategies. (FT)

Taxation without representation American tax policy is skewed in favour of whites, argues Emory University law professor Dorothy Brown. Its disparities could negate any progress made towards racial financial equality. (BBG)

Going Dutch The Netherlands feared that the UK's exit from the EU would bruise its economy. Yet Amsterdam is blooming into an unlikely financial contender in a resurgence reminiscent of Tulip Mania. And it has Brexit to thank. (FT)
